intro: Balsamorhiza hookeri var. hispidula, commonly known as the hairy bitterroot, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its hairy, rough-textured leaves and yellow composite flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its medicinal properties. Its scientific name reflects its geographic origin and distinctive hairy appearance.
